title: Part I: The Union and its Territory
content: India is referred to as a Union of States, indicating that its unity cannot be broken.
The Indian Union cannot split in two.
Specifies the structure of the Union Government and the state governments.
Divided into numerous regions known as states or union territories.

title: Part II: Citizenship
content: Articles 5 to 8 describe who was eligible for Indian citizenship at the time of enactment.
Articles 9 to 11 define how citizenship is obtained and lost.

title: Part III: Fundamental Rights
content: Guarantees basic rights and remedies in the event that they are violated.
Protects individuals from collective action or state overreach.
Heavily influenced by the US Bill of Rights clauses.

title: Part IV: Directive Principles of State Policy
content: Guidelines for the government to establish social and economic justice.
Article 37 declares these principles are non-justiciable (cannot be upheld through legal channels in court).

title: Part IVA: Fundamental Duties
content: Inserted by the 42nd Amendment Act of 1976 based on Swaran Singh Committee recommendations.
Stipulates 11 Fundamental Duties for Indian citizens.

title: Part V: The Union
content: Union Executive (Articles 52â€“78)
Union Legislature/Parliament (Articles 79-122)
Union Judiciary/Supreme Court (Articles 124-147)

title: Part VI: The States
content: State Executive (Articles 153-167)
State Legislature (Articles 168-212)
State Judiciary/High Courts (Articles 214-237)

title: Part VIII: The Union Territories
content: Ultimate decision-making authority belongs to the Parliament.
Governed directly by the Centre through an administrator chosen by the President.
UTs lack the conventional autonomy found in states.

title: Part IX: The Panchayats
content: Article 40 directs the state to organize village panchayats.
Covered by the 73rd Amendment to enhance local self-government in rural areas.

title: Part IXA: The Municipalities
content: Defined under the 74th Amendment Act of 1992.
Concerns the organization, authority, and duties of urban self-government entities.

title: Part IXB: Co-operative Societies
content: Added by the 97th Amendment Act of 2011.
Focuses on social and economic justice through cooperative self-help groups.

title: Part X: The Scheduled and Tribal Areas
content: Fifth Schedule applies to the administration of Scheduled Areas and Tribes in most states.
Sixth Schedule applies to Tribal Areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram.

title: Part XI: Relations between the Union and the States
content: Legislative relations (Articles 245-255)
Administrative relations (Articles 256-263)

title: Part XII: Finance, Property, Contracts, and Suits
content: Governs the transfer of properties, assets, rights, and liabilities.
Covers the executive power of Union/States to engage in trade and enter contracts.

title: Part XIII: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse
content: Guarantees freedom of trade, commerce, and sexual activity within Indian territory.
Based on models found in the Australian Constitution.

title: Part XIV: Services under the Union and States
content: Concerns hiring, working conditions, and protection of public employees.
Establishes Public Service Commissions (UPSC and State PSCs).

title: Part XIVA: Tribunals
content: Quasi-judicial organizations for administrative or tax-related disputes.
Established by the 42nd Amendment Act of 1976.

title: Part XV: Elections
content: Vests authority in the Election Commission for the conduct of elections.
Article 324 grants extensive powers to ensure free and fair elections.

title: Part XVI: Special Provisions for Certain Classes
content: Safeguards for Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, Backward Classes, and Anglo-Indians.
Concerns reservation of seats in the Lok Sabha and State Assemblies.

title: Part XVII: Official Language
content: Outlines the official language of the Union (Articles 343-344).
Official languages are listed in the 8th Schedule of the Constitution.

title: Part XVIII: Emergency Provisions
content: Allows the federal government to become a unitary government during crises.
Three categories: National Emergency, President's Rule, and Financial Emergency.

title: Part XIX: Miscellaneous
content: Protection of the President and Governors.
Barring of courts in certain treaty disputes and abolishion of privy purses.

title: Part XX: Amendment to the Constitution
content: Addresses the power of Parliament to amend the Constitution.
Designed to be neither too rigid nor too flexible.

title: Part XXI: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
content: Includes Article 371 to 371-J to meet aspirations of backward regions.
Protects tribal cultural and economic interests.

title: Part XXII: Short Title, Commencement and Repeals
content: Concerns the short title and commencement date of the Constitution.
Contains authoritative text in Hindi and repeal of previous acts.
